channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: More Brutal Fighting Expected in East
item.description: Moscow’s advancing forces threaten Lysychansk, the last major urban center in Ukrainian hands in Luhansk province. Ukrainian forces are bracing for another bitter fight in neighboring Donetsk province.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: At Least 1,000 Killed in Afghanistan Earthquake, Officials Say
item.description: More than 1,600 others were injured in the 5.9-magnitude quake, which struck early Wednesday and was centered in the country’s remote southeast near the Pakistan border.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Bakhtar News Agency, via Associated Press

item.title: In South Africa’s Farmgate Scandal, a Theft and Then a Silence
item.description: Namibian investigators tracing money transfers by men suspected of stealing wads of cash from President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa say their cross-border calls for help went unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Tileni Mongudhi and John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, right, campaigning before local elections last year. This year, he is in the thick of a battle to be re-elected as leader of his party.

item.title: Libyans Try to Move On From Conflict With Comedy and Burgers
item.description: After more than a decade of chaos and war, fed-up Libyans are clamoring for peace — and making clear they’ve had enough violence: “We want to taste life, not death.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Saudi Prince Visits Turkey For First Time Since Khashoggi Murder
item.description: The 2018 killing and dismemberment of the Saudi dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul drove a deep wedge between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, right, on Wednesday with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on his first visit to Turkey since the murder of the Saudi dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul in 2018.

item.title: Analysis: What Turkey Wants to Let Finland and Sweden Into NATO
item.description: Finnish and Swedish hopes of being accepted as applicants by next week’s NATO summit meeting have been dashed by a Turkish government that says it is in no hurry.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Finnish soldiers during NATO military exercises this month on an island in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: Mykolaiv Keeps Defying Russia’s Attacks on Ukraine’s Black Sea Coast
item.description: Without its Black Sea coast, a landlocked Ukraine would struggle. Mykolaiv is determined that won’t happen.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Svetlaya, 67, whose home in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, was hit on Friday.

item.title: ‘Not in This for the Money’: Why Some Families Sue North Korea
item.description: Families whose relatives have been abducted or imprisoned by North Korea are seeking to hold the country financially accountable despite the long odds of collecting money from the isolated nation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Choi Byung-hee, whose father was abducted by North Korea, holding the only picture she has of him. She is seated with her aunt and uncle (and her father’s siblings): Choi Cha-moon, 86, left, and Choi Tae-boon, 79, at Mr. Choi’s home in Seoul in June.

item.title: Israeli Government Collapse Gives Netanyahu Another Chance at Power
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, lost power last year. But his base hasn’t abandoned him, and he could return to office after a snap election this fall.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, speaking at a protest in April, has vowed to return to power.

item.title: Why Does Israel Have So Many Elections?
item.description: Israelis are heading back to the polls for the fifth time in under four years.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, left, speaks during a joint statement with Foreign Minister Yair Lapid, at the Knesset, Israel's parliament, in Jerusalem, Monday.

item.title: China’s Surveillance State Is Growing. These Documents Reveal How.
item.description: A New York Times analysis of over 100,000 government bidding documents found that China’s ambition to collect digital and biological data from its citizens is more expansive and invasive than previously known.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Paul Mozur, Isabelle Qian and Alexander Cardia

item.title: China’s Expanding Surveillance State: Takeaways From a NYT Investigation
item.description: Times reporters spent over a year combing through government bidding documents that reveal the country’s technological road map to ensure the longevity of its authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian, Muyi Xiao, Paul Mozur and Alexander Cardia
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: In Ukraine, One Woman’s Shopping Trip Over the Last Bridge in Lysychansk
item.description: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Russia Gains in Eastern Ukraine, Threatening to Overrun Luhansk
item.description: The seizure of three strategic villages confronts Ukrainian commanders with a grim choice: fight on and risk encirclement or retreat and lose the last major centers in the region.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Ukrainian service members in Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Devastating Earthquake in Afghanistan Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead
item.description: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah, Alissa J. Rubin and Mike Ives

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Deadly Earthquake in Afghanistan
item.description: Also, a pivotal showdown looms in Eastern Ukraine and China squeezes Taiwan’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Bakhtar News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Some of the destruction in the province of Paktika, in eastern Afghanistan.

item.title: Businessman Tied to China Alibaba Rape Case Gets 18 Months
item.description: A court found Zhang Guo guilty of “forcible indecency.” The tech giant fired his accuser last year after she claimed that he had molested her and that her boss had raped her.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: The incident attracted national attention last year when the woman, known by only her surname, Zhou, screamed about it at an Alibaba cafeteria.

item.title: Kaliningrad Is Again a Flash Point in East-West Relations
item.description: Wedged between Poland and Lithuania and bristling with missiles capable of flinging conventional or nuclear warheads into Europe, Kaliningrad has become emblematic of the Cold War era.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kaliningrad’s House of Soviets was never fully occupied but still towers over the remains of the Prussian Königsberg Castle, which the Soviet authorities demolished in the 1960s.

item.title: When Gun Violence Outrage Isn’t Enough to Bring Reform
item.description: An examination of crises in the Americas — including school shootings in the U.S. — yields a sobering theory about why even a national outpouring of pain cannot always overcome political divides.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police in São Paulo, Brazil, in 2020.

item.title: A pivotal showdown approaches in eastern Ukraine as more villages fall to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian tanks and military vehicles heading toward the village of Toshkivka on Sunday.

item.title: A Pro-Religion Court
item.description: What the 6-3 conservative Supreme Court majority’s latest ruling means.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington.

item.title: Finding New Route for Ukraine’s Grain Exports Isn’t So Simple
item.description: Proposed alternatives include exporting into Poland or transporting it into Romania and out through the Black Sea port of Constanta.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A storage facility for grain in Boryspil, Ukraine. World leaders are working to find new solutions for exporting Ukraine’s agricultural products.

item.title: Boris Johnson Risks a Sharp Rebuke in U.K. By-Elections
item.description: Scandals, economic pain and an uproar over lockdown parties have left Britain’s Conservatives at risk of losing both recent advances and old strongholds.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Lightwood, center, is the leading opposition candidate in Wakefield, where a member of Parliament for Britain’s governing Conservatives resigned after a sexual assault conviction.

item.title: How Sabyasachi Made the Sari Haute
item.description: As his country’s most famous designer, Sabyasachi has persuaded Indians to see the luxury in their fashion heritage. Can he persuade Americans too?
item.dc:creator: Francesca Mari
item.media:credit: Zishaan A Latif for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sabyasachi at home in Kolkata.

item.title: The Netrebko Question
item.description: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko is opera’s biggest star. But her career is in disarray because of her ties to Putin, and arts companies around the world are divided on whether to welcome her back.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández

item.title: Funerals in Lviv Show Growing Toll of Ukraine’s War
item.description: The funeral for a marine who loved the sport of parachuting was the first of four on Tuesday for local soldiers killed in heavy fighting against Russia in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners prayed and sang during Artemiy Dymyd’s funeral at the Lychakiv cemetery in Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday. Mr. Dymyd was killed in battle while serving in a special operation unit of the Ukrainian marines.

item.title: Ukrainian Black Sea Strikes Suggest Arrival of Western Weapons, Analysts Say
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it was attacking Russian infrastructure on Snake Island.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian weapons hit Snake Island, off the coast of Odesa, as well as a former natural gas rig where Russian forces had placed radio-jamming equipment, a former top defense official said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Asia buys up Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Oil tanks at a crude oil terminal near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Companies Brace for Impact of New Forced Labor Law
item.description: Billions of dollars could be at stake as a law banning imports of some products from China goes into effect.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Container ships waiting to enter the Port of Los Angeles last year. Enforcement of a new law could lead the U.S. authorities to detain or turn away a multitude of imported products.

item.title: The U.S. confirms the death of an American presumed to be the second killed on the battlefield in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

item.title: A shopping trip for apples, over the last bridge in Lysychansk.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: How Russia Is Making More in Oil Sales Now Than Before the War
item.description: With China and India buying the Russian oil shunned by the West in an effort to force an end to the Ukraine invasion, Moscow is earning more now than it did before the war.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Clifford Krauss and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: As Russia renews shelling in Kharkiv, the civilian death toll is growing, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukrainian civilians return to cities that bear the scars of war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Asia Buys Up Russia’s Oil
item.description: Also, a Times investigation into China’s expanding surveillance capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: The Yang Mei Hu oil products tanker moored at a crude oil terminal in Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Biden Bans Most Antipersonnel Land Mine Use, Reversing Trump-Era Policy
item.description: The move effectively returns to a 2014 policy that forbade the use of the weapons except in defense of South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and John Ismay
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers searched for land mines in the Demilitarized Zone in 2018. The Biden administration is maintaining an exception for land mine use along the heavily militarized border between North and South Korea.

item.title: Many parents in the U.S. have tough questions about the vaccines for young children.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Timothy Ivy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunny Baker, 35, of Oxford, Miss. said she is eager to get the vaccine for her daughter, Alma Pearl Baker, 2. “We would love to be first in line.” she said.

item.title: Documenta Takes Down Art After Antisemitism Accusations
item.description: Organizers of the international art exhibition in Germany said they would remove a work after diplomats and lawmakers said it contained antisemitic images.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Uwe Zucchi/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: “People’s Justice,” a nearly 60-foot-long painted banner by the Indonesian collective Taring Padi, was covered over on Monday. Documenta’s organizers said on Tuesday they would begin removing the work.

item.title: Merrick Garland Visits Ukraine to Discuss Russian War Crimes
item.description: In an unannounced trip, the U.S. attorney general met with prosecutors and said perpetrators of atrocities have “no place to hide.”
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick Garland met on Tuesday with Ukraine’s prosecutor general, Iryna Venediktova.

item.title: S​outh Korea Launches Satellite With Its Own Rocket for the First Time
item.description: The launch brings the country closer to its ambition of becoming a player in the space industry, no longer reliant on technology from other countries.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Nuri, South Korea’s first domestically produced space rocket, lifting off from a launchpad at the Naro Space Center in Goheung, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: Asia is buying discounted Russian oil, making up for Europe’s cutbacks.
item.description: The shift has allowed Moscow to maintain its production levels and defy analysts’ expectations that its output would plunge.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: The Yang Mei Hu oil products tanker moored at a crude oil terminal in Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Jumbo, Hong Kong’s Floating Restaurant, Sinks After Capsizing
item.description: Jumbo Floating Restaurant, which closed in 2020, capsized in the South China Sea after being towed from the city. The sinking triggered nostalgia for a happier period of Hong Kong history.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Jumbo Floating Restaurant being towed out out of Aberdeen Harbor in Hong Kong last week.

item.title: The Painful Path to Fight Inflation
item.description: The government’s plan to fight inflation could cost jobs and restrict wage growth.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Shopping for food in Brooklyn last week.

item.title: Australian Judge Delays Brittany Higgins Rape Trial
item.description: A journalist’s remarks ran afoul of tight limits on speech connected to criminal prosecutions, putting pause on a high-profile case about to start.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins in Canberra, Australia, in February. Her allegation of being sexually assaulted by a colleague while working in Parliament drew attention to what many women described as a toxic workplace where sexual harassment was pervasive.

item.title: Chinese Omicron Study Renews Debate Over ‘Zero Covid’ Policy
item.description: The study found that the variant carried a relatively low risk of severe illness.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Beijing last week.

item.title: Finding Traces of Harriet Tubman on Maryland’s Eastern Shore
item.description: A historian marks the 200th birthday of a fearless conductor of the Underground Railroad with a visit to her birthplace, only to learn how climate change is washing away memories of “the ultimate outdoors woman.”
item.dc:creator: Martha S. Jones
item.media:description: No place better remembers the abolitionist Harriet Tubman than Maryland’s Eastern Shore, where she was born enslaved 200 years ago. Much of her story is told through its land.

item.title: 1972: A 36-Day Hunger Strike Ends in Northern Ireland
item.description: Irish Republican Army members imprisoned in a Belfast jail called an end to a protest that lasted more than a month.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: A Russian journalist’s Nobel medal sells for $103.5 million.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitri A. Muratov won the Nobel Peace Prize last October.

item.title: U.K. Hobbled By Largest Rail Strike in Three Decades
item.description: Travel was disrupted for tens of millions of people during the country’s biggest walkout in decades as union leaders warned of a summer of labor unrest.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)
item.media:description: Waterloo Station in London on Tuesday. After last-ditch talks between the main union and the rail operator collapsed, hundreds of trains ground to a halt for the first of three planned days of strikes.

item.title: U.S. officials predict more gains for Russia, but stronger pushback from Ukraine in the east.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers last month aboard an armored vehicle heading toward the front line near Kramatorsk, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A small town has become a turning point in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the scene of at least one missile strike hit what appeared to be a military depot in the eastern Ukrainian town of Druzhkivka Monday night.

item.title: U.S. Officials Predict Path of War in Ukraine
item.description: As Russia makes slow but steady progress, the arrival of new weapons systems will help Ukraine hang on to territory, U.S. officials and analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers atop an armored fighting vehicle in an area near Kramatorsk, in the Donbas region, early this month.

item.title: Russian Journalist’s Nobel Medal Sells for $103.5 Million
item.description: Dmitri A. Muratov, the editor of the independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta, will donate proceeds to UNICEF to help Ukrainian child refugees.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitri A. Muratov won the Nobel Peace Prize last October.

item.title: 132 Civilians Killed by Rebel Attacks in Central Mali, Government Says
item.description: Several villages near the town of Bankass were attacked over the weekend by jihadists, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: The head of Mali’s ruling junta, Col. Assimi Goita, declared three days of mourning.

item.title: Gustavo Petro Promised to Transform Colombia as President. Can He Do It?
item.description: During his campaign, Gustavo Petro proposed major reforms if he was elected. After winning Sunday’s presidential election, he’ll now have to prove he can carry out those changes.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro, center, and Francia Márquez, first from right, celebrating after winning the presidential election on Sunday in Bogotá.

item.title: Russia’s Blockade of Ukraine Is ‘War Crime,’ Top E.U. Official Says
item.description: The remarks by the official, Josep Borrell Fontelles, were among the strongest language from a Western leader in describing the Kremlin’s tactics to subjugate Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the scene of a missile strike on what appeared to be a military depot in the eastern town of Druzhkivka on Monday night.

item.title: ‘We Are Not Safe’: Ethiopians Flee Massacre That Killed Hundreds
item.description: The massacre in Oromia, the nation’s largest region, came as the country grappled with a grueling civil war and the worst drought in decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Security forces in the town of Jimma, in the Oromia region of Ethiopia last year.

item.title: Kremlin Calls Captured Americans ‘Soldiers of Fortune’
item.description: Moscow says the Americans who fought for Ukraine are not regular soldiers who would be covered by the Geneva Conventions, calling their conduct criminal.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
